description.text: Fraemes are your interchangeable, swappable, personalizable 3D-printed wonder-case. Designed by amazing artists from all over the world, the multi-part design (a 3D-printable insert, which you can pop in and out, and a rubber bumper) allow you to update your look as often as you please. If you haven’t already snagged your bumper or if you want more designs, you can get them on our website, here: http://www.fraemes.com/makerbot Have any questions? Just want to say hello? Don’t be shy - drop us a line at [email protected]

Fraemes are easily printed on your MakerBot using the high quality options in Makerware (ideally, use 0.1mm layer height, 40% infill, and no raft). You can use your favorite filament of choice (Fraemes are a perfect match for the MakerBot glow in the dark and photochromatic filaments). We've included a single file for your MakerBot Replicator and two smaller files for your MakerBot Mini. If you have any other questions, contact us at [email protected]

author: kayvan

description.text:
A printable selector valve for diverting fluid to different directions.
.
This was designed with aquaponics / hydroponics in mind but may have many other uses. Its all customizable too, so there are lots of options, for example:
  • Valve can be servo controlled, or manual.
  • Any size + number of outlets you want, as well as multiple inlets so it can tee into the middle of a line.
    .
    This is a work-in-progress and has not been physically tested yet. See the instructions tab for details.

Critical Improvements Needed:
1) Improve maths to get housing diameter from number of selections and hole size
2) Add o-rings so it won't leak. See: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:225603
3) Account for servo angle range (much less than 180, and what I have now would require 360)
4) Is the off position even necessary? In between any two selections is off!
.
Possible Improvements:
1) gearing?
2) Possibly make more printable somehow?
3) A mounting bracket to affix it to something
4) Spring-loaded?

comments.text: Very interesting design. I'm in the midst of designing a greenhouse watering automation system, and this one would come in handy. I suggest that the design be broken up in parts (f.i. the selector plate and the housing needs to be printed towards the 3D printer glass plate for smoothness), Multiple parts can then be glued together, and be designed for this.
comments.author: robiwan

title: Learning to Model for Print (Video Series)

description.text:
When I am not creating / inventing new things here on Thingiverse, I am an instructor at a local Career Tech Center in the field of Digital Media.
Teaching Junior and Senior high school students the latest in all things digital. Anyway I have 3D printers in the classroom and students wanting to print things who have never touched a 3D application in their life. I want them to be able to create things.
Not just download from thingiverse and print but actually make and print stuff of their own. One of the things I like doing is breaking down problems into chapters, and back everything I teach with videos. This way they have a reference point. I usually post the video series on youtube but use the video files themselves in the classroom. So I am inviting the community to the show. If you're new to 3D printing and have never modeled before this would be a great start for you.. This class focuses on software vs hardware, Design vs durability, and shows you workflows for many different situations that you come accross trying to produce a good printed part. I am using Blender-Slic3r-Printrun in the workflows, but really it translates well to other applications as long as you follow the same terminology. youtube.com/playlist?list=PL7tGtxtIW0Iw6Vghav13UoPPAtPFTGe0I Are you a slow learner and need an extra slow course before you hop into printing? http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL2BA5BDF79FF50122 If you have ideas for examples that would be good for new developers as far as small lessons that do not take up huge amount of plastic post them here! This remains a work in progress until all chapters have been produced. As things are made for the series I will post the stls here. So if you see something you might want to try and make you have an example here to look at. I ask to keep the troll level down a notch maybe , I know certain audiences like to kill the messenger before they physically try something or hear something mispronounced and raise their pudgy little arm.. So yes you linux and ard-ween-oo users I am talking to you ;) In the heat of polygon land battles my last thought is my slipping of the tongue. So keep in mind young users watching the videos on youtube also.... Keep it clean or I will delete the comment. Other than that enjoy!

comments.text: Jason- I have to dsay thanks for all your work on Youtube! I have watched many, many hours of your Blender videos, as well as quite a few fo the Zbrush ones as well! Great stuff and very much appreciated. WIthout them, I wouldn't know what I am doing in Blender at all!

author: t0bi

description.text:
This prehistoric Native American pot is decorated with stylized human hands and bones. This model is based on a scan available from http://hampson.cast.uark.edu/ . The Arkansas museum has scanned their large collection of prehistoric native american pottery and made the scans available for download.
The scans are beautifully detailed, but unfortunately in their raw form they aren't printable. The scanner can only capture the outside of the vessel and so it provides only a non-manifold surface which can't usually be printed.
I brought the original scan into 3Dcoat, solidified the model and carved out the inside using the voxel editor. So anyone using this model for scholarly study must remember that while the outside is based on the scan the inside is entirely my own work and is no reflection of the actual artifact.
We talked about this thing and a whole lot more about 3d printing on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/

author: kayvan

description.text:
This is a cup holder I am making for a store. It is meant to hold fountain cups (44oz and under) and is stack-able and expandable. There is a top piece which you may add as many as you wish to reach desired heights, a lid if you decide you want one, and a base. 
(sorry the models are backwards :()

Add logos or labels, and at least print the bottom piece. You may print as many top pieces needed to reach your required height. There is also a lid if you wish to use it. There are 1/4" holes to insert a bolt and washer to hold together.

Derived my Pen Holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26277, in turn derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12707), this diaper bin accurately fits a roll of plastic bags so you can refill it with an entire roll and just throw out the old ones when they are full (or smelly :-)

Cut, assemble and glue the edges between the side and the bottoms.
Notice that this design is optimized for wood, since acrylic probably does not bend that well. The first one I made was made with HDF, but the bends are a little too brittle. The round corners broke after a couple of months, while this (in birch plywood) has been in use since february without any problems...
If you do not have a laser cutter wide enough, use the "short" files. You will need to cut two sides and the two bottoms. These files should fit even the smallest laser cutters (fits nicely into my VLS 2.30)...
the total height is 14.57844 so just scale it to your desired height

description.text: For all of you rock collectors out there, here's a 3D-printable stand for your geode slices, up to 5/32 of an inch thick! Soon, I'll have more sizes for people with biger slices, and stands for your other rocks and minerals as well.

For slices 1/8 - 3/16 in. use the "rockholder" file.
For slices 1/4 in. use the "rockholder B" file.
For slices 5/16 in. use the "rockholder C" file.
Print using a raft.

Are you hungry yet? This giant size version of America's Favorite cookie is based on a photoscan. I shot 150 pictures of an actual Oreo using a Nikon DSLR with a 40mm Macro lens. Then I ate the Oreo while waiting for Agisoft PhotoScan to crunch the data. Like any self-respecting Oreo this one can be unscrewed. I modeled the "Stuff" since actual Oreos aren't threaded. The model is scaled to the largest size I could print on our SeeMeCNC Orion Deltabot. A Rostock Max could get almost Claes Oldenburg size.
To make your own print two wafers in black and the male and female "stuff" in white. Assermble with the glue of your choice. I use PVC pipe cement. We talked about this thing and a whole lot more about 3d printing on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/

title: Re-sizable Picatinny Attachment
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Picatinny rails are not all the same - some are a tiny bit bigger, some are just a tiny bit smaller. I designed this re-sizable mount that could be printed as one model, but still can move. In order to secure it properly, use M4 screw (about 38 mm in length) and an M4 nut.   
It is just the attaching mechanism, so feel free to add anything you want to it. I am uploading the STP file and the IPT (Autodesk Inventor) file.   
Happy Shooting!.
Print it. Then gently (or not so gently, depending on your 3D printer) squeeze it together to free the moving part.

author: Yurevich

title: Iggy Broc
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Well, I came into the office today to be greeted by a mystery print sitting on the build plate. Perhaps creating this Picklomancer character wasn't such a good idea. I went to the kitchen to make my mid day coffee and to my surprise there seemed to be a band forming in the fridge. I grabbed the cream for my coffee thinking this must be in my head. I went to put the cream away and it turns out, I wasn't seeing things. The rotten broccoli print had relocated himself to the fridge to hang out with Eggy Rotten. I murmured to myself, "How the heck did this broccoli print get in here?!". Only to have an answer spit right back at me. "Hey junk bag! The name is Iggy Broc!"

Iggy Broc was sliced in ReplicatorG with no supports... so Picklomancer tells me. He recommends a raft to keep the print stable. Picklomancer then colored in the X's in the eyes with a fine paint brush and acrylic paint.

author: yourwildworld

description.text:
This is a "clip on" mount for the EC board, with an added option for a fan base to keep it cool.
I developed this idea as a way to allow for a simple interchange between the extruder and the Unicorn pen plotter. No more bolting on and bolting off of the controller from one tool to the next.
I have uploaded the stl files of the controller mount and the fan plate, along with the rar file of the SolidWorks assembly.

Fabricate the components with a 3D printer and assemble with six M3 by 16mm bolts, six M3 nuts and suitable standoffs.
Simply slide the assembly onto the MakerBot's acrylic z-stage and position it appropriately so it will not obstruct traveling of the Z-stage.
To place the 40mm by 40mm fan, I simply used hot glue. Note: Printing the controller mount with its maximum surface area on the build platform would result in a faster build time, but the clip would be weaker.
Sidepanel of a Moto Morini 3 1/2 motorcycle

I found inconsistencies between the various models I could find of the Smart LCD controller boards for RAMPS, so I measured and modeled one directly. The one I have is from: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Reprap-Ramps-1-4-smart-LCD-controller-with-smart-adapter/711091101.html Edit (2013-07-09): Updated files to correct discrepancy in LCD screen position.
Put in your CAD assemblies.  I included the Solidworks 2012 file and a STEP file along with the STL.

comments.text:
Three Tips:
1) When printing my first several tries fell over mid print. I used dark blue painters tape that gave it a firm adhesion. The tape had to be washed and scrubbed off. (Don't use very hot water as it will soften the print. )
2) Painting it helps give enough friction to keep it together and reduces the tolerances to give a reasonable fit.
3) Hint for puzzle: put like shapes together first.

comments.text: Yes, definitely! But it wouldn't be customizable unless it was written as one of their shape scripts. The hinge is very simple: the middle part has cones that stick out from either end, and the side parts have slightly larger cone-shaped holes that trap the middle piece. When the piece prints layer by layer, the hinges trap each other but never touch, so there is nothing to break or snap after printing.

This is a mecanum wheel based off of Zaggo's design. I beefed up the area around the bearings and made the rollers a little wider. I found that without the thicker area around the bearings, the plastic cracks and breaks off. I have uploaded two versions. One accepts an 8mm shaft and the other accepts the standard 5mm stepper motor shaft.
A short video of their operation:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NohwUDOjMZY

Print two regular wheels and two mirrored wheels. Each wheel takes 16 rollers. I printed the wheels at 70% infill and the rollers at 40%.
To assemble 1 wheel the following is needed:
8x M4x60mm bolts
8x M4 nuts (lock nuts are ideal)
8x 624 bearings
32x M4 washers

comments.text:
Nice job.
What are the main differences between this design, and design like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2520? What are the pros/cons of each one? What about this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:267422?
I would like to make tiny omniwheels for an hexapod, to move it faster on flat surfaces, and I'm looking for the simplest solution...
Thanks.
comments.author: fma

comments.text: Omniwheels work differently than mecanum wheels. An omniwheel has rollers that are parallel to the hub of the wheel. A mecanum wheel has rollers that are set 45 degrees from the hub of the wheel. If you do a search on youtube for omniwheel and for mecanum wheel you can find some videos that show robots that demonstrate the different ways the wheels work. If you were going to make small wheels, I would try to find a design that maybe doesn't use bearings, because then you could scale the design down. Otherwise you would have to find small bearings that would fit. This mecanum wheel design uses 624 bearings.
Thanks for you answer!

description.text: A folding bone you can put your name on

I use a folding bone for test-folding printed sheets in the printshop where i work. They are pretty hard to come by these days so i designed one myself. When i get my hands on some nylon i will print one with it. PLA just isn't tough enough to withstand many folds. I uploaded the .skp file so you can customize your own in Sketchup.
Just place text on the surface (on intersect plane) then explode the text component and push/pull the text to the desired depth (i used 2 mm's).

title: PS3 Controller mount and Trigger repositioning

description.text:
This s a PS3 Dual Shock controller non destructive mount that re-positions the L1 and L2 triggers to the Right hand side for gamer's that may have limited functionality
I also included a base that can be secured to the mount to allow you to mount your controller to a tripod.
If you wish this to position the trippers to the left side mirror the 2 .Lever models, the Trigger and the Button files. You can also mirror the upright and top lever to suit your needs.

Print required parts for your needs.
Must have parts are the following:
L2trigger
L1Button
R2lever
R1lever
FacePlate
Leftarm
Rightarm
2 #6-32 x1-1/2in Machine Screws are used to secure levers in the faceplate. Triggers must be able to move freely.
I used Case Fan Screws to secure the other parts of the model.
http://www.amazon.com/Black-Computer-Case-Screws-Pack/dp/B00785I5ZM/
For the tripod mount I used E-Z Lok Threaded Insert, Brass, Knife Thread, 1/4"-20 Internal Threads, 0.500" found here :
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00207NF6W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

description.text: I'm in the middle of a project that uses multiple BMP085 pressure sensors and wanted a way to test the output of my code.  Here is a test chamber that uses a column of water to maintain pressure.  The water column half of the cylinder has four notches.  The First notch is at the top of the  hole between the two chambers.  There is a notch every inch above that.

1: Print
2: Inspect for any cracks, unless you like water all over your desk.
3: place sensor in side sensor box,  seal up any wires with epoxy, hot glue, or whatever works.
4: insert sensor box into hole on top of the test chamber,  seal it up.
5: Add or remove water and watch your sensor register the change

remixed_from.title: Anatomic Human Foot & Lower Extremity Version 2.0

title: Astragalus bone - Ancient precursor for dice and jacks games - Knucklebone

description.text:
The astragalus or talus bone, the ankle bone, usually taken from goats or sheep. Used in games of chance and skill since at least 3500 BC.
When tossed in the air, they will land with one of four sides face up, sometimes referred to as Camel, Goat, Horse and Sheep (see photo). Because of the irregularities of each bone, the probabilities of landing on any side are not equal as they are for dice. Games evolved with these differences in mind.
See these two Wikipedia entries for some games that use these bones:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knucklebones
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shagai
This particular astragalus bone was extracted from a model of a human foot skeleton. Not the traditional source, but it works well enough! Perhaps ideal for Halloween games.
Printed in ABS, 40% fill.  Print with support for the bottom surfaces only.

This what is known as a net, eight cubes, that when folded in four-dimensional space, will form a hypercube. There are actually 216 different combinations that will form a hypercube. I chose one that had no overhangs, so can be printed without support.
If you find yourself in hyperspace, this link will lead you to a color-coded graphic, to let you know just how to fold the 3D printed object:
http://www.matematita.it/personali/index.php?blog=7&cat=196
There are several 3D printable "models" of hypercubes or tesseracts around, but they are only projections, a bit unsatisfying to me. This model could really be "folded" into a hypercube. It is "4D READY".
As shown, printed in ABS without support.

title: Taz Lead Screw Stiffened X Ends

description.text:
Upgraded my Taz 3.1 to 4.0 specs with a new Z axis Lead Screw. The Taz 4,0 has an aluminum plater the X ends, z Nut and Z bearings attach to.
Being in the middle of nowhere and no machine shop, I printed the X End Plates. These worked but had a lot of flex in them. SO I redesigned the X ends so the ends are integrated with plate and stiffened them up.
Included is the freecad file and ini file for PLA I used.

comments.text: Hi, I printed your parts, and they helped a lot with the wobble. Where did you get those limit switches and the adjustable position screw? The stock switches don't quite fit. Thank you so much!

comments.author: chiphead420

comments.text: You are a life saver!   I spend the last two days doing the upgrade and I had problems with Z wobble with the normal parts.    I was wondering,   did you have any issues with your lead screws?  I bought my from Misumi and I was wondering if they are contributing to the wobble issues.  Although,  it looks like these parts have solved that problem so far.

remixed_from.title: Parametric two-part mold generator for OpenSCAD

description.text:
No Kitty! That's my chicken pot pie kitty! No Kitty! No! Now you can cast Fat***, I mean Cartman from a mold and use him to taunt everyone. I tried to get rid of the vinegary Oogoo smell this time by adding Vanilla oil...now cartman smells like vinegar and vanilla :P. Also note my funky two tone mold caused by me having to change filament partway through the print. I used Oogoo, you can find the recipe for Oogoo here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/How-To-Make-Your-Own-Sugru-Substitute/
Oogoo sets in less than 10 minutes so printing molds is a great way to build an army fast :).
Have fun.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hEMCEIX58bi

Well really more of a minimug-- the inside volume is pretty small compared to the overall size. Mixed tool flow between Blender and TopMod. Steps: Took a cube in TopMod and cleaved off the edges to make an octagonal prism, scouped out the inside and subdivided, then did one of those checkerboard scoups from this tutorial: youtube.com/watch?v=fwSV89_syBM With one subdivide to make sure it was still manifold, I took it into Blender and manually added the bridge at the base between the upper brane and the lower one, which will allow it to print. (I couldn't get TopMod to quite grip the faces I wanted.) In addition I sharpened the tops of the holes in the outer brane to make them more printer-friendly. The Double-Brane Mug is heavily influenced by this one:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:434
(Topologically speaking mine's an inside-out version!) I've included the last TopMod file before export to Blender for comparison and ease of hacking on it.

description.text: Fraemes are your interchangeable, swappable, personalizable 3D-printed wonder-case. Designed by amazing artists from all over the world, the multi-part design (a 3D-printable insert, which you can pop in and out, and a rubber bumper) allow you to update your look as often as you please. If you haven’t already snagged your bumper or if you want more designs, you can get them on our website, here: http://www.fraemes.com/makerbot Have any questions? Just want to say hello? Don’t be shy - drop us a line at [email protected]

Fraemes are easily printed on your MakerBot using the high quality options in Makerware (ideally, use 0.1mm layer height, 40% infill, and no raft). You can use your favorite filament of choice (Fraemes are a perfect match for the MakerBot glow in the dark and photochromatic filaments). We've included a single file for your MakerBot Replicator and two smaller files for your MakerBot Mini. If you have any other questions, contact us at [email protected]

description.text:
This beautiful carved totem pole stands overlooking Tumwater Falls in Tumwater Washington.
All pictures were shot from ground level with Nikon D5000 and a Nikor 18-55 set to 18mm.
Examining the model carefully reveals some interesting things about the photoscan process. The right side of the pole has much better detail than the left. This is because the sun was shining from the right making the pictures shot from that side much better than the back-lit photos shot of the other side. Also the quality of the scan deteriorates as you move up the pole. This is because the pictures shot close to the ground were shot from much closer, producing better data than the more distant shots of the top. I did some retouching of the eagle wings and the base of the eagle which was not visible from the ground.
We talked about this thing and a whole lot more about 3d printing on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/

comments.text: Nice photo-scan, all you really need to do is chop it down the middle and mirror the right side over to the left. I can do this if you want me to. Nice work.
comments.author: MustangDave

comments.text: You are welcome to do it if you like.  I didn't because the loss of detail isn't very apparent when it is printed small, although you can sure see it in the model.  Also because it is hand carved it is unlikely to be truly symmetrical.  Be sure to post a remix if it comes out.
comments.author: MustangDave

comments.text: I actually did a remix with the mirroring (link under remix), and it came out pretty decent, the pole is "symmetric enough" to look pretty good,  The only thing really noticable is the cross-hatching on the beaver....
comments.author: Shapespeare

comments.text: Ok, I drew a centerline down the middle of the model and you are right, it will not be able to be mirrored since it does not line up all the way down with the carved art. Oh well, it was worth a look. Still a great scan.
comments.author: Shapespeare

comments.text: Will do, you are right, it's not meant to be symmetrical, but once I'm done with it, it will be:)

description.text: BoB a fun introduction to the world of walking robots for children and adults alike! with simple construction and very low part count you can have your bob up and walking in no time. i've updated recently to include the BoB poser software by robotfreak modified from the fobo poser software just load the arduino code onto the controller and plug in BoB to usb and get posing! it allows a frame by frame sort of capture mode and playback making animations easy

you need: printed parts 1 X head 1 X base 2 X bracket 2 X feet electronics 4 X 9g servos micro controller of choice (ardiuno nano fits nice) battery (nimh 9v, lipo, AAAs, whatever you have that works) sr04 or ping 3mm leds a little tip. for faster printing feet in cura you can "sink" the print down 2.5mm it takes about 10 minutes off the print time

description.text:
A two-part thing for mounting something in the cigarette lighter of your car.  
The bottom of each section has a hole to accommodate a #10 screw.
This could really be improved by recessing the bolts into the convex parts of the top.
Print it, clean up the holes with a 1/4" drill and bolt together.

I have to tune my Guitar quite often to Drop-D, and back to standard E. Due to a free swinging Floyd Rose Tremolo, the Tension changes with that, and all the other strings have to be adjused aswell, thats quite time consume, because every the tension lowering is kind of a chain reaction.
Thats what these Backboxes are for, they block the FR at the back, so it won't go down any further.

you'll nedd 2psc M4x35 (at least, i used M4x50), 2pcs M4 nuts, 2psc wood screw (I used 3x15)
attach as the picture shows, at standard Tuning. If there are still problems, thighten the spings of the Tremolo, or adjust with the M4 Screws oft the backbox.
Works perfectly in my Ibanez
Caution, Tremolo works only in one direction after you attached this, im fine with it cause i do standard bendings for upper pitches. Maybe there could be made a spring loaded Backbox (like original ones) to work around.

comments.text: Nice idea - I did a similar thing on my Jem using a locking bathroom door bolt (eg: http://tinyurl.com/j2v6jqs) and a small cut-away in the trem cover so i can lock and unlock it easily.

title: SSD adapter in low-profile floppy bay

description.text:
My IBM Thinkcentre has only one 3,5" bay,CD and floppy, and I wanted to add a SSD hard drive while keeping the old disk as storage.
The computer is a special small form factor and the floppy drive has also a strange form factor.
It is a Sony MPF820 and its dimensions are L130 x W96 x T12,7mm
This thing is an adapter to install a thin 2,5" SSD in this [strange dimension} floppy bay (1,44MB heh, who needs that?)

This is just two side rails. There are holes to screw the ssd from underneath, but it wasn't possible in my setup, I had to screw it from the sides..
Print one as it is
Print another one but mirrored
Install and enjoy.
On the picture I show my setup besides an adapter for a regular floppy bay (Thing #10519, wider but shorter)

comments.text: NOTE THAT THIS IS NOT A STANDARD 2.5" to 3.5" ADAPTER!  It's NOT designed to fit to a standard 3.5" drive opening.

The battery cover on our Keysonic wireless keyboard (http://www.ebuyer.com/product/104608) broke: the prongs failed resulting in a failed power, lost batteries and intense frustration. So we printed a new, improved replacement cover. Yes, 3d printing can produce something useful! The original cover was recreated in qcad. The areas that experience most strain were reinforced with ribs or by thickening, while the flexibility of the latch was increased by lengthening the slot in the cover. After the second round of printing we had something robust, with a snug fit, that keeps the batteries in. One risk of the current design is that the support buttresses for the prongs are quite fragile and can be torn off in the printing process. This can result in malformed hooks, but in our case everything came out fine. The keyboard cover was printed on a Stratasys Dimension 768 SST, with breakaway support material. Feature resolution is 0.5mm.

To print a keyboard cover for a Keysonic keyboard, just use the STL file.
If you need to modify it for a different keyboard or remote control or miscellaneous battery thingy, start with the DXF.  It consists of five layers: "front", "top" and "bottom" provide the corresponding perspectives of the object, while "remove" is used to trim away some artefacts from the extrusion process.  Layer 0 is used for construction lines and not utilised in the creation of the STL.  
Openscad was used to create an STL.  The SCAD file extrudes the various layers in the DXF and assembles them into the final object.  If you have made significant changes to the DXF, it may be necessary to modify the positions of the faces in the SCAD file.  Export the new STL model from openscad, and you should be ready to print.

Belt holder for the Y axis.
To prusa I3 steel, Y axis clamping between the bed and the belt. Designed in two heights and maximizing the useful travel of the bed.
Includes a pretensioner for easy positioning of the belt.
Timing Belt model G2.5

• Corrected the rotation of the parts for printing.
  • Added detail to the instructions.

• Print all parts.
  • First mount the fixed part (back and support).
  • Ensure that the belt is aligned with the center of the stepper before tightening the M3x25 screws with washers and nuts. (recomended from up to down: screw, split washer, washer, bed, support, back, nut).
  • Attach the belt as tight as possible on the moving part (front).
  • Ensure that the belt is aligned with the center of the bearing.
  • move the piece to back and tighten the M3x12 screws with washers and nuts. (recomended from up to down: screw, split washer, washer, bed, front, nut).

This is an predecessor to Mouthpiece 2.1:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44422 After I successfully printed the working Trumpet mouthpiece yesterday, I learned OpenScad and made a parametrized version.

I print these in ABS at 20% infill and 0.2 mm layer thickness and sand the rim with fine sanding paper. OpenScad:
I set up the parameters to be the same as my Vincent Bach 5 mouthpiece. I'll start playing with the parameters from there. Impact of the parameter on properties info from Wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mouthpiece_(brass) Parameters:
CupDiameter=16; // [Trumpet ~16] Larger Cup Diameters are optimized for lower ranges, giving a richer tone. Smaller diameters assist high range playing. CupDepth=11; // Shallower cups greatly assist playing in high ranges but do so at the cost of fullness of tone. Deeper cups assist low range flexibility and rich tone. CupSphereFactor=0.8;// [0 (Conical) - 1 (Spherical)] Spherical cups have brighter, more projected tones, while conical cups have less tone definition. RimWidth=6; // [~6] Wider rim widths reduce the pressure on the lips, allowing greater stamina. It does, however, reduce flexibility. RimRadius=2.5; // [~2.5] Lower rim radius reduce stamina but increase control. More smoothed rims are commonly found on deeper cups. ThroatRadius=2; // [~2 ] In spherical cups, a sharper throat contour gives a more harsh, projected tone and a rounded contour gives a deeper, richer tone. Conical cups with a smooth throat have less definition. ThroatDiameter=3; // [Trumpet ~3.5] Larger throat diameters give more volume but less control. Smaller diameters have much more control but significant volume limitations. BoreDiameter=8; // [Trumpet ~8] More conical backbores give a richer tone, while more cylindrical ones give a brighter, more projected tone. FrontPipeDiameter=13; // [Trumpet ~13] BackPipeDiameter=10; // [Trumpet ~10] MouthPieceLength=87; // [Trumpet ~87]

title: Ultimate GoPro Camera Clamp for Ultimaker 2

description.text: This clamp fits snugly on the front top of an Ultimaker 2. You can mount the GoPro camera on the side as well as on the top of the Ultimaker 2. The clamp slides smoothly across the printer in order to orientate the camera.

Print is as orientated. Use support for the two GoPro brackets. Printing at 0,2mm PLA 50% infill gives an excellent and solid result.
When mounting the clamp lower it vertically down onto the upper front rim of the Ultimaker 2.

comments.text: I used to hand make stuff a lot like this about 22 years ago (mostly with soldering or glueing), this sort of design builds more pressure than a normal centrifugal pump. It combines centrifugal pumping with axial flow and radial flow impeller characteristics. The motor loading characteristics for a centrifugal pump are for less loading on blockage, for axial flow and radial flow the load increases. On one like this, you can build in fairly constant loading characteristics for the motor even if it's blocked.

description.text: A small monument erected to the memory of siblings who died within a year of one another. It is dated to the late 1870s. It has some slight issues in that I should have taken more photos of the top as there are a few nearly inconspicuous over-corrections in the lamb when I closed the holes in the mesh. The monument itself is badly worn from over a century of exposure to the harsh climate of South Dakota. The inscriptions are not easy to read, but I think they can still largely be decrypted with the right raking light. The base of this model looks goofy as the original was surrounded by tall grass and Photoscan just ignored it when creating the model.

I used a 50mm manual focus lens on my Nikon D200. I set it to f/22 at 100 iso. Finally I used a tripod to steady my camera and focused as carefully as possible (something that is still a little tricky for me since I'm mostly used to the camera doing the focusing work).
I shot about 15 RAW photos.
I imported them into Adobe Lightroom and then checked them for proper focus, exposure and made adjustments wherever necessary. I then exported the corrected photos as 16-bit TIFs.
Next I masked all the photos and saved the masks as PNGs.
For the final step, I imported the TIFs & PNG masks into Agisoft Photoscan Pro and set it to the highest possible output for detail and accuracy.
I usually export the finished models as PLY files since they contain both the mesh/3D information and the texture maps/surface information as a single file. Most of the time, the PLY files seem to be a bit smaller than OBJ files, but I'm always happy to export to whatever format is easiest for anyone to use.
I have found that Meshlab is superb open source software for exporting models into a variety of file formats if you would prefer to grab my models and do the conversion yourself.

comments.text: What file format is PLY?
comments.author: MustangDave

comments.text: I'm so new to all this, but what I've seemed to notice is that PLY files contain all the information about the visual appearance/texture of the object plus the mesh/3D information in one single file. It also looked like it was a little bit smaller than a standard OBJ file too. But, I can happily upload whatever format is the most universal for anyone here.
comments.author: MustangDave

comments.text: I would be happy to see OBJ, 3DS, or STL files available. I think you would get more downloads if you had those to offer.

This is a super high resolution copy of Dragon DOMO sunglasses.
I´ve scanned this on a 100 000$ professional grade STEINBICHLER L3D scanner using an automatic remote turntable.
Unfortunately, I broke my original sunshades a couple of weeks ago.
The lens was still ok, so I thought, why not copying that thing.
The 3 scans (3x14x16=672 images ;-)) took about 7minutes + another 10 minutes of post processing and cleaning.
CHECK the INSTRUCTIONS section for more details.
SORRY for NOT uploading the original scan files, but I do not want to violate any copyrights.

The 1´st attempt was an abs print at speed 80, 0.2mm layer and 50%infill without support.
Lifted up from the heated glassbed at about 90% due to warping...
So, at the second attempt, I printed with raft on kapton tape and support at 50mm/s and with 25%infill+cooling.
...and it came out really fine after exactly 4h6minutes.
Some 15minutes of sanding and assembling and it was done.
This was actually my first print with sainsmart ABS, and I´m super stoked about the HUGE DIFFERENCE this material makes to the stuff I´ve used recently.
It just prints soooo much better, looks way better and has a semi glossy finish.
And it´s tough. You can bend the frame in all directions, way more than the original one.
It´s more lightweight and even when you touch it, it feels not really like
abs...
Don´t know, but that stuff is simply great.
I really thought, that there can´t be so much difference within the different ABS materials, BUT i was wrong. Sliced with Cura for Mac

comments.text:
Thanx!
I was really surprised about the quality, it which it came out on the second attempt.
I just say Saintsmart filament.
But by the way, I´m not sponsored by them, but really impressed by the difference ;-)

Telecaster knob for a 2mmx5mm switch blade; usually used on American Telecasters and replacement switches.
The tolerances are purposely a bit tight so that you need to gently force it on so that you don't loose it, like you do most other switches.
To have a smooth finish print in ABS and give the part an acetone vapor treatement.
This self designed and printed knob sits on my self designed and build Telecaster. How cool is that, that these days we can pretty much produce it all at home.

See this wikipedia article:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_Borromean_rings
Chemists took on the challenge of creating a compound with the structure of the famous Borromean rings, three rings linked together among which no two are linked. The compound depends on six zinc ions, represented by the balls in the photo, for its synthesis and stability.
The STL provided is scaled to fit glass marbles, 16mm in diameter. It can be scaled to fit other sized balls, for example the pinball version also pictured.
Echoing the actual compound, this model tends to "lose its marbles" unless all of the marbles are fitted in place.

Printed in place, prelinked.  This requires a lot of support.  After printing and cleaning up, place the marbles, which are locked into place by slight concavities on the inside edges of the rings' curves.  Make sure the rings are all mutually perpendicular for the balls to stay in place.

description.text: A 3/11 or 11/3 gear box made as a toy. Can be used as a demonstration example or a weekend project.

This is a toy gear set built as an experiment/ prototype. I made mine from 6mm MDF (I know, its a pattern with my designs). I actually deviated from the design shown by using 2x 6mm washers either side of the frame spacers rather than using 3x spacers. You can follow the assembly to see what you'll need in terms of parts and quantity. 24.01.13 Update For those who are looking to build this, youâ€™ll need 1x Planet_Spider_1
16x Spacer_6mm
1x Spacer_3_6mm
2x Frame_1
1x Internal spur gear_MOD 3-5 42t 20deg
3x Gear_MOD 3-5_12t_20deg
1x Gear_MOD 3-5_18t_20deg
1x Planet_Spider_3
2x Drive Boss 18mm dia dowel (length to suit)
3x 12dia x 20v lg dowels You'll also need:
4x M6x45 hex head bolts (or equiv.)
Superglue
8x M6 washers (if you want to cheat like I did)
1x M6 Penny Washer (for a thrust washer- use anything that is to hand) Build as follows:

  • Assemble the input shaft (18 tooth gear, Drive boss and Spacer_3_6mm). I added a thrust washer to the face of the gear in the form of a penny washer.

  • Connect the other drive boss to Planet_Spider_1. Add 3 no. 12dia x 20 lg dowels to the spider, add the three 12 tooth gears and cap off using the Planet_Spider_3. Make sure the gears spin.

    1. Build the frame up by stacking Frame_1 â€“ Spacer (x2, or 2x 6mm washers and 1x spacer) â€“ Internal Spur Gear â€“ Spacer (x2, or 2x 6mm washers and 1x spacer). Donâ€™t add the other frame yet.

  • Insert one shaft assembly into the frame. Add the other shaft into the assembly.

  • Finally, add the other frame and fit the bolts. These shouldnâ€™t need nuts (mine didnâ€™t as the wood was a tight fit).
    • Iâ€™ve included the source files to allow you scale to suit. The module for the gears used is 3.5. If I've missed anything, let me know. That's it. Enjoy. UPDATE - Photos of my build added

comments.text: I'm using the anti vibration mount and arm on my gimbal (I already had the remaining parts for a mobius). Overall this works well, but I am having trouble with strong vibrations when turning or changing altitude especially. If I shake the copter in my hands, the gimbal bounces around quite a lot. This seems to be the anti-vibration balls being too soft.. which type are you using for this? The ones I use are 100g load/each, but are already the lowest weight balls I found for this size.
comments.author: Arakon

comments.text:
it could be down to a lot of things it could be your gimbal control board setup, balancing of the gimbal arms with the motor weight and cam weight, esc calibration, torque of the gimbal motors. Gimbal PID settings its also impossible to eliminate all vibrations (high and low frequencys) the best thing to try is buying a variety of dampeners and seeing which works best for you, every setup
Is different. The rest of the assembly that you have is it made out of plastic or aluminium, 10g40? Do you have a video I could see of first and third person view? What gimbal control board and motors are you using?
comments.author: Arakon

comments.text:
The rest is also all 3D printed. I'm fairly sure the vibration is down to the actual gimbal assembly shaking. I previously had it set up as hanging from the rubber balls, and the vibration was less and it moved less (by hand). I then set it up as pushing on the rubber balls (which is supposed to be a lot more effective at damping vibration), with this 3d assembly, and it now seems to shake more.
http://youtu.be/3LuJ4CDf59g especially torwards the end of the video.
comments.author: QuadFramesUK

comments.text:
Pretty good video, it's not far from perfect :) I think you are correct with it being down to the dampers, I think we tried 3 different strengths 50g, 100g and 200g (yellow dampers) for testing and if I can remember rightly the stiffer the better the quality in the picture, unfortunately 200g was the stiffest we had. I would by a couple of packs of 150g upwards to the stiffest you can find and see what works best for you. When you have time
Would you mind uploading
An I made one along with a few of you videos and what worked best for you for others to see that would be great.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:356988 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=356988

Okay so it isn't really a cube, but that doesn't make it any less awesome. This nifty little thing was created by Kris Pister at UCLA and basically tells you everything you ever wanted to know about silicon (from a microfabrication standpoint) i.e. different crystal planes, etch rates in various solutions, crystal structure, etc. The original is made out of paper and meant to be glued or taped together, but after an unfortunate incident involving a falling textbook I have discovered that it is not very robust this way. 
On the off chance that you don't actually care about silicon but want to print it anyway, it makes a nice Christmas tree ornament!
I've included a hollow box version with a lid, a braced box version, and a full-blown solid version, depending on how much plastic you want to use.
Update: I uploaded a letter-sized version of SiCube.pdf (the cube itself is still the same size). I also uploaded new pictures since I totally made the first one wrong =(.

If you are printing a box version, print the lid and one of either SiCubeBox.stl or SiCubeBoxBraced.stl. Glue the lid onto the box. Print and cut out SiCube.pdf (you can cut off the glue tabs) and glue the pieces onto your printed cube.
If you are printing the solid version, you only need to print SiCubeSolid.stl and glue the paper pieces as above. As an added bonus, the solid silicon cube can also be used for self-defense.
I've only printed out the hollow box version so far and there is some warping on the sides but nothing too serious. The braced version should fix this.

description.text:
Hi there. This is my take on the Fallout 3 Gauss Rifle. Its not screen accurate but its how I would imagine it if I made it full scale from mdf, fibreglass and bondo.  
Scaled at 1/6 so great for a miniature.  
Im open to commissions if you want something made so hit me up.  
I make props for a living and just like to share my designs with teh 3d printing community. Please don't sell as your own model.  
Any comments would be grateful.

I made this using autodesk 123d as its a excellent free program and can give you some great results once you get used to it. When printed comes with lots of support and takes alot to remove but some careful hands and you can hold your own gauss rifle.
